subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Anti-patterns
msgSnippet: ... I don t understand the problem. If two implementations of List have equal elements at the same indices, equals() returns true for them. At least, it does
messageBody:
Stephen Smith wrote:
> I'd suggest using Assert#assertEquals(String,Object,Object) to compare
> two different java.util.Collection implementations (e.g. ArrayList,
> Arrays.ArrayList) - but there's no real API-based solution to that one
> unfortunately. If there's one comparison I tend to trip up on, it's that. :(

I don't understand the problem. If two implementations of List have
equal elements at the same indices, equals() returns true for them. At
least, it does for every implementation of List I've ever used, and I
use the Collections and Arrays methods quite frequently.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info
Your guide to software craftsmanship
JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
